titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of Holdings at the University of Houston Libraries

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was encoding in EAD scripts by Archon system scripts from a SQL database source on June 13th, 2007.

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: The Professor Joseph S. Werlin Papers contain extensive newspaper and magazine articles relating to international issues of interest to Dr. Werlin. Topics include, but are not limited to, politics, racism, nationalism, agriculture, birth control, and many others. Most of the materials date from the 1940s and 1950s, there is also a limited amount of personal material, including correspondence and photographs, in the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Professor Joseph S. Werlin was a charter member of the University of Houston faculty, having joined the Division of Social Sciences when the University was founded in 1934. He served the University with distinction and enthusiasm for 30 years.

As a man of many scholarly interests and accomplishments, Dr. Werlin was widely known as the founder and director of the University of Houston International Studies Center, and conducted educational tours for students to Latin America and Europe for over 19 years. Dr. Werlin's efforts toward furthering knowledge and understanding of the Latin American peoples and their cultures were recognized not only in the academic world but also by the governments of both Mexico and Guatemala.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Professor Joseph S. Werlin Papers contain extensive newspaper and magazine articles relating to international issues of interest to Dr. Werlin. Topics include, but are not limited to, politics, racism, nationalism, agriculture, birth control, and many others. Most of the materials date from the 1940s and 1950s, there is also a limited amount of personal material, including correspondence and photographs, in the collection.
Forms part of the University Archives.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of Materials
arrangement.p: The collection arrived at the archives in relatively good order, which has been maintained where possible. For preservation and access reasons, the collection has been re-boxed and re-foldered. New folder titles conform, as closely as possible, to original folder titles, except when the original was obviously incomplete, incorrect, or confusing. Original folder and item order has been maintained whenever possible including the vernacular of the period. Exceptions were made when folders were obviously misfiled or when no order was apparent.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This Collection is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

controlaccess.head: Corporate Name:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Houston. Latin American Studies Program

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Professor Joseph Werlin Papers, Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

scopecontent.p: This series consists of three folders related to Professor Werlin's various activities at the University of Houston.

did.unittitle: University of Houston - General Faculty Matters
University of Houston - General Faculty Matters
University of Houston - Sociology Department Matters

scopecontent.p: This series contains twenty-one folders of correspondence between Dr. Werlin and various family members. Included in this section are also a limited number of family photographs. The folders have been arranged in chronologically.

This series contains eleven dated speeches and sixteen undated speeches given by Professor Werlin between the years 1934 and 1942. This series is divided into two sub-series the first is arranged chronologically by date of the speech. The second set of speeches was not dated and thus was arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: This series contains forty-four folders dating from 1942 - 1954, arranged alphabetically. Included in this series are notes, correspondence relating to international study abroad opportunities at various universities including Cuba, Guatemala, and Mexico.

did.unittitle: Cuba: General Information - Hotels, Transportation, Tr. Folders.
Project: College Years in Mexico - Dr. Van Riper (Benjamin W)
Summer Centers: Programs, Budgets and Memoranda I

scopecontent.p: This series contains seventy-four folders of newspaper articles and other research materials used by Professor Werlin for his classes. The sub-series is arranged by the course number, with the original folders titles maintained including the vernacular of the period. The newspaper articles cover a wide variety of topics including: education, religion, races, urbanization, birth control, old age, among many others. These materials relate to Professor Werlin's Sociology courses 231 to 573.

did.unittitle: Soc 331: Fish &amp; Algae &amp; Other Water Food
Soc 333: The Urbanization of The United States
Soc 334: Communism: USSR &amp; Communism Bloc States in Europe. Economic: Industrial &amp; Agricultural.
Soc 334: Internationalism - Political, Economic, Scientific, Cultural
Soc 415: USSR - As World Leader &amp; Power
Soc 432: Juvenile Delinquency: Control And Prevention

scopecontent.p: This is the largest series in the collection and contains one hundred ninety-one folders, arranged alphabetically. A partial listing of topics include: history, political and sociological issues around the world including England, Ireland, Germany, Pakistan, Japan, China, and Russia. Many of these articles appear to be taken from newspapers and magazines from the country of origin. Original folder titles were maintained including the vernacular of the period.
